body: I'm aware of this, and I'd also prefer special handling of those and other line drawing chars. However you should provide a way to use font line drawing glyphs instead of builtin ones.

> I'm aware of this, and I'd also prefer special handling of those and other line drawing chars. However you should provide a way to use font line drawing glyphs instead of builtin ones.

Since it has been long confirmed that custom handling is the only way to solve these issues reliably, I'm not completely against custom handling these anymore. I still hate it, but it makes sense. An option to disable this should definitely be present though.

issue.title: Gaps between individual colored cells
issue.body:
Hey, I have been using Alacritty for a few weeks now and so far I am loving it. I also use kitty every now and then and notices how kitty has no gaps between cells. How do I achieve this in Alacritty? 

I am running qtile on Arch Linux with picom as my compositor.

Difference (left kitty, right alacritty):
![terminals](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68782626/133910564-cfa0ec95-1fcc-4ebd-82ee-4d0d5af7d816.png)

alacritty.yml:
```
import:
- /home/ralts/Downloads/alacritty-master/dracula.yml

env:
  WINIT_X11_SCALE_FACTOR: '1.0'

font:

  normal:
    family: FiraCode Nerd Font Mono

  bold:
    family: FiraCode Nerd Font Mono

  italic:
    family: FiraCode Nerd Font Mono

  size: 12.0

  offset:
    x: 0
    y: 0

  lyph_offset:
    x: 0
    y: 0

draw_bold_text_with_bright_colors: true

colors:
  primary:
    # background: '#0f0f0f'
    background: '#0d0d0d'
background_opacity: 0.92

window:

  padding:
    x: 4
    y: 4
```

body:
For comparison, [foot](https://codeberg.org/dnkl/foot/src/commit/9a04c741a094b97f4502d4c098fca8c19cb3647b/terminal.h#L343-L356) handles these ranges:

- 2500..259f (box drawing)
- 2800..28ff (braille)
- 1fb00..1fb9b (legacy computing)

issue.title: fzf border is ugly.
issue.body:
The fzf.vim plugin border is not rendered as I am used to for some reason.

On konsole, it looks like:
![konsole](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22935110/145694172-67b11d5a-e566-41fa-a82b-e81080bf1357.png)

While on alacritty it looks like:
![alacritty](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22935110/145694176-6a70047a-fbd4-4dbb-ae5b-d379b384bfe5.png)

Both consoles are using the same Ubuntu Mono Nerd Font. In the screenshot, the font sizes are slightly different, but this does not change the issue.

Obviously not a terrible bug, but it makes me wonder whether I have configured something wrong.

### System
OS: KDE Neon 5.23
Version: alacritty 0.10.0-dev
Linux/BSD: X11, KDE

body:
> > I'm aware of this, and I'd also prefer special handling of those and other line drawing chars. However you should provide a way to use font line drawing glyphs instead of builtin ones.
> 
> Since it has been long confirmed that custom handling is the only way to solve these issues reliably, I'm not completely against custom handling these anymore. I still hate it, but it makes sense. An option to disable this should definitely be present though.

Why do you hate it, @chrisduerr ?

Because it completely goes against font configuration to ignore the font **explicitly chosen** by the user in favor of shipping your own shitty bitmap font (or whatever it might be). It's completely backwards.

> Because it completely goes against font configuration to ignore the font **explicitly chosen** by the user 

Sure, just provide a boolean config that toggles this behavior. Also, mind, all major TEs I tested (Kitty, Konsole, Gnome-Terminal, iTerm2) are in fact even having that feature and even enabled by d fault. So my point is, the user might even have expect this behavior. Otherwise, click the toggle. :)

> in favor of shipping your own shitty bitmap font (or whatever it might be).

No need to get personal, @chrisduerr. I was expecting some respectful communication here. ;)

>  It's completely backwards.

I hoped I have made my point clear in the top that this is not backwards. 
But I agree, this would be yet another if-condition within the rendering hot path that may potentially be a threat over performance. I hope though that would be neglectable.

> Sure, just provide a boolean config that toggles this behavior. Also, mind, all major TEs I tested (Kitty, Konsole, Gnome-Terminal, iTerm2) are in fact even having that feature and even enabled by d fault. So my point is, the user might even have expect this behavior. Otherwise, click the toggle. :)

A boolean option toggling between two broken behaviors doesn't make any of them less broken.

> No need to get personal, @chrisduerr. I was expecting some respectful communication here. ;)

I'm not, I was speaking in general. Alacritty will do the same in the future and it will still by our own shitty bitmap font.

> I hoped I have made my point clear in the top that this is not backwards.

You have not. This is completely backwards and I doubt anyone would be able to change my mind on that. I'd say it would be pretty much objectively superior if terminals could use the font's glyphs without rendering artifacts.

> But I agree, this would be yet another if-condition within the rendering hot path that may potentially be a threat over performance. I hope though that would be neglectable.

This shouldn't have any impact on performance really, those glyphs can be cached at startup and don't ever need to be updated unless the font size is changed.

> A boolean option toggling between two broken behaviors doesn't make any of them less broken.

It's the font providing not so optimal block elements. One could say that this is broken indeed. At least as much as fixed size grid systems are concerned.
But why the other system, making sure block elements are rendered as specified in the terminal is broken you have to tell me. I do not understand.
But even so, let's assume both **are** broken, then having a toggle isn't that bad after all, don't you think so? The user has the choice to decide what looks best to him, which, by definition should be the latter, and if one opts to get the former, just do so. 

In my opinion, that's usability. :)

> and it will still by our own shitty bitmap font

Okay, this is your words then. Maybe you need to help me understand what you mean by "by our own shitty bitmap font"? What's so shitty about being pixel-perfect?
Are all other terminal emulators doing it wrong then?



> >  I hoped I have made my point clear in the top that this is not backwards.

> You have not. 

lol. okay. Let's call it language barrier then. ;)

> This is completely backwards

?

> and I doubt anyone would be able to change my mind on that. I'd say it would be pretty much objectively superior if terminals could use the font's glyphs without rendering artifacts.

Okay, granted. No problem with that, but then please close this and *all* the tickets related to that. This at least would make it very clear to the users that you simply don't want that. And nobody will be waiting hopelessly. Probably the same for the Sixel discussion then. 

Cheers.

> But even so, let's assume both are broken, then having a toggle isn't that bad after all, don't you think so? The user has the choice to decide what looks best to him, which, by definition should be the latter, and if one opts to get the former, just do so.

Well it is *that* bad, because it's still broken. It might still be the best choice, but that doesn't make it **good**. That's why this issue is still open and planned to be implemented. It sucks, but it's still the best choice available.
i lag definition of broken in this context. I'd really like that to be clarified. Okay, nice to keep it open, really, but how do you think this can be implemented in an "unbroken" way then?

issue.title: Use builtin font for box drawing unicode characters
issue.body:
This commit adds hand rolled drawing of unicode box drawing[1] and
block elements[2] from ranges U+2500 up to U+259f. While using system
font for such characters will look better most of the time, the
characters tend to overlap or not align, so providing builtin font is
the lesser evil here.

[1] - https://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/U2500.pdf
[2] - https://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/U2580.pdf

Fixes #5485.
